Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy is super helpful and really willing to take the extra time to explain things which is great. HeÂ´s going to make a good professor.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was a great course - but I do think it should be worth 4 credits.

Question 8 - - It'd be great to space the field trips out a bit more so they are not all in the beginning. I found myself getting a little sick and tired of them when they were one right after another,but would've loved one later in the course.
Extremely well thought out and well taught. excellent.
Overall, great course â fascinating material clearly presented.
The main out-of-class assignment-- reading responses-- weren't super useful for me, though they did get me to closely read certain papers.

This was the best class I have taken at FES to date. I found the professor to be dedicated to teaching the substance, very patient and thorough, very responsive and willing to make himself available to students, whether through multiple exam review sessions or private meetings. In sum, a pleasure to learn from.The course did a fantastic job of connecting science to policy, while still be firmly based in the science. I believe this should be the balance that all FES classes aspire to strike, but have not found that to be the case. I also found the student presentations to nicely complement the substance of the course, successfully allowed us to gain deeper exposure on specific issues. Personally I learned a lot through the student presentation process and found that independent research process to be a very satisfying test of knowledge accrued through the course. I also found the one page article summaries to be unexpectedly challenging, but a very useful exercise, both in terms of acquiring skills for science writing and for parsing out scientific literature.My only criticism might be regarding the coverage of evaluative indicator systems for the final session. As a capstone or opportunity for synthesis of the materials covered over the course of the semester, I'm not sure what would be a better fit, but I found this subject (and the last chapter of Valeila) to be underwhelming generally.Thank you for the great course.
Great class overall. The field trips were extremely helpful in reenforcing material covered in class. Wish there were more field trips.
I loved this class and the TA and professor were just amazingly helpful.

I thought the course was well designed and well executed--all while maintaining a necessary degree of flexibility and responsiveness to students' needs and concerns. The syllabus was obviously carefully thought-out and balanced. The in-class experience was captivating and informative, even if it was a bit slow at times due to the long single class period each week.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trips to reaffirm the material! Also, it is evident that Shimi truly cares about the students and wants to make sure we understand the material!
Excellent professor, really engaging material, and his clear commitment to teaching it to us so we really understood it.

The field trips were outstanding. We did a ton of learning and I think really became familiar with the marshes. It was a little sad to stop visiting them for the second half of the course. Maybe we could incorporate one final one (up to that site in New London?) on a Friday?Loved guest lecturers. All did an excellent job - especially Penny Howell and Andy Kemp. That definitely switched things up and kept the class moving.Doing reading summaries was slightly tedious, but I think I would walk into class with a pretty good understanding of those key papers rather than my more typical speed read. I also like that we didn't follow up with a super dry "discussion" about what the papers said - you just took us through them to ensure we really understood methods, findings and criticisms.Similarly, studying for quizzes seemed annoying at first, but absolutely solidified our knowledge week after week. I appreciated being able to ask questions to clarify things that had been confusing during the prior week, even though that took up some time. I think the points we would hit were confusing for each person in the class and brought our understanding up to the next level.I liked learning about studies that you and Troy were really involved with (and Andy Kemp and Penny Howell for that matter). Definitely appreciated hearing from the experts.I really liked the combination of learning foundations of coastal ecosystems, management issues/practices and reading key papers that go through scientific findings. I thought it was a great mixture of material. Also our few discussions were quite enjoyable. There were so many people in the class who are experts or whose past classes have given them fascinating experiences.
The teacher expertise and enthusiasm.

We spent alot of time discussion salt marshes so the the field trips were great opportunities to see exactly what we studied in class.Professor Anisfeld was one of my favorite professors this semester. He was informative and accessible and showed concern for his students learning.

I'd say the material itself is really interesting. The course is a crazy rapid survey of everything coastal, but while you might occasionally get a little overwhelmed, ultimately it feels more comprehensive than confusing. You have to be really engaged by coastal science to take this course; if you are, you'll find the material and the pace exactly right.
Thoroughness of coverage of salt marsh ecosystems
Field trips were the best aspect of the course. It was extremely helpful to go out into the field and physically see the environment that we were learning about in such depth.
See above.
Instructor and TA knowledge about subject matter. Guest lectures also helped broaden concepts covered in class. Coffee and cookies were also great!
ItÂ´s a LOT of material. So I really felt like I got my moneyÂ´s worth with this class. The field trips are great. Shimi makes sure youÂ´re really understanding everything.

It's balance of science with just the right amount of management, policy, and conceptual applications sprinkled in. As a non-scientist, I thought this balance was maintained remarkably well. The readings were informative (if slightly redundant in some areas--i.e. PHAU control) and the field trips weren't simply excuses to get out.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The workload - weekly quizzes, responses, and large amounts of reading, plus a final, presentation, and paper are a bit much.Reading responses could be eliminated - at this stage in my academic career, I do the reading, I felt that it was just busy work.
This is a small detail, but slides with graphs and charts on them need to have the whole caption from the paper so we can study.

I think quizzes should force you to study, but should be easy to do well on if you study. There were a few questions that weren't that clear and tripped up the majority of the class. I think better to use quizzes as a check point than a trap.I didn't always follow the order of why we were addressing certain topics. I know that was tricky because you wanted to hit so much material and it is all related but also all over the place. I don't know if I have a suggestion for how to address this. Zonation was a clear theme that we returned to a couple of times, but not in order - so maybe grouping more of that together?The class should start at 1:10 to accomodate Wed lecture speaker series (I know that's a administrative issue not you). The length of time is tough. I generally could stay focused for the first 3 hours and then had trouble retaining the last bits of information. Switching between different speakers/quiz/cookies/presentations definitely helped.In terms of making use of the experts around us, I think it might be cool to offer up opportunities to go out into the field with you, Troy and Andy to help collect data. Not sure about quality control issues/requiring this, but I think some people might really enjoy seeing how collecting this data actually happens. Perhaps a few Friday opportunities?I didn't like the Valiela (I know, not Variela) textbook. Is there a more Tarbuck type textbook for coastal ecosystems? I just didn't like the style or his outlook that much.Seems like there are some marsh experts up at Conn College. Any chance we could meet up with them? What about an opportunity to meet with an oyster co to hear about their side of management. I think Becka Schultz went to Norwalk the other week and had a good experience hearing about their management issues.The final covers an incredible amount of information, and given that there is no midterm, took a lot of time to review for. This is nitpicky, but I think it would be helpful if it were one of the later exams during the exam period.Finally, the part of the class that was most frustrating were the student presentations. I think there is a lot of opportunity to learn from others in our class, but the given time made it pretty much impossible to provide a decent explanation of background and 2 papers. Here's my suggestion. Stick with the 9 minute preso and 3 minutes of questions. The in class presentation portion can be all background with some bits and pieces on interesting studies. Then the paper could be minimal background and a more in depth look at studies. I guess the utility of this exercise depends who its for. Maybe each student better understands their two studies by explaining them to the class. But the entire class might better understand 15 topics if we just learned the background and some tidbits of studies as a supplement. Like I said, it's impossible for you to get to all of the topics of coastal ecosystems, so it seems like a great opportunity to spread out the teaching. You could even offer up 30 sub-topics that you don't have time to teach that people could give us the 10 minute basics of. The 3 page limit on the actual paper was tough to stick to. I think we need four pages to do a good job. We also could have used more information about what you were looking for.
None.
I understand that Professor Anisfeld's research focuses on salt marshes and that why we spent so much time on them. I would have appreciated a deeper discussion of other types of coastal ecosystems.

Shimi teaches the class in a rather piecemeal way, involving a lot of jumping around from topic to topic. Partly that's because he's seeking to break up the four-hour class length, which I understand and appreciate; but still, it made things occasionally perplexing... it would have been helpful if the salt marsh lectures, in particular, had been delivered in a more logical and sequential fashion.

The reading responses seemed unnecessary and time consuming. I think that it would be almost impossible to do well in the class without reading all the materials, and I felt like almost everyone can read and understand scientific articles. I really enjoyed the last couple discussions and hearing about people's varying aspects on the issues.

The name of the course is definitely a bit of a misnomer. It would probably be better to call it 'Marshes: soup to nuts'. But I like marshes and it was good to go into depth, but if thereÂ´s a way to spend just a bit more time on other systems (like say a field trip to a rocky intertidal?) it would be even better.Maybe assigning topics for student presentations could be one way to help balance the course?

Probably a slight tweak here or there to the readings paired with lectures. It seems that we jumped around a little bit, especially towards the end of the course, and re-visited some things we learned earlier in the semester that were at odds with the earlier semester's teachings/materials. While it became clear that this was intentional and with purpose, it could have been explained a little better to the students so as not to confuse us.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I thought the field trips were good - I would have liked more discussions.
Great labs.
n/a
No lab sections.
Absolutely. The field trips did a wonderful job of giving the course, and the science at its core, a hands-on, tactile learning aspect. I could have done more field trips personally!
Office hours were helpful

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Very knowledgeable and accessible.
Troy was great â didn't aggressively insert himself, but was very reliable when called upon for assistance. He's clearly very knowledgeable about all things coastal, especially marshes.
Troy did a great job. Very approachable and knowledgeable.
Troy was an efficient, knowledgeable TA. He was fair, responsive, and shared expertise when asked. Couldn't have been better.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  He really didn't take an active role in the class aside from his lecture. I would have liked to get his input and hear from him more.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy clearly knows a lot, but I found him hard to follow conceptually.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy did a great job on field trips, in his lecture and in explaining basic concepts.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy was available, helpful, knowledgeable, all-around great.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Troy was always accessible and friendly when I needed help.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  Good and helpful overall.
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  See above
Instructor: Troy Derek Hill  HeÂ´s really willing to help. I think he could work on his lecture style a bit to have a bit more of an arch to the story, but really on whole very very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It is directly aligned with my career goals.

While I know quite a bit about ecology, much of my past studies have focused on forest systems. This will help me to teach a more complete set of topics and depending on where I end up geographically, I definitely plan to lead some field trips to coastal ecosystems and perhaps to teach sub-sections in future classes that focus on coastal issues.
Water quality.

I'm taking all the water and coastal/marine classes I can here at FES (it's pretty slim pickings, unfortunately), so the tie-in is pretty obvious. This course fit well into that general course of study, and filled in many of the scientific gaps that Coastal Governance had left for me.
Interested in aquatic ecosystems and how to deal with disturbances to those ecosystems.
I wish there were more science focused classes like this one in FES.
IÂ´m interested in coastal issues so this was perfect and I wish there were more classes on this topic.
I'm a non-scientist with 6+ years of terrestrial natural resource management experience--mostly on the policy side and mostly dealing with energy.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I want to be a water resource manager.
Interest, because I had heard Shimi was a great professor, and because of the field trips. And because it's a science course, not a management course.
To round out my ecological education and because Shimi is a solid teacher.
Shimi is awesome!

Again, I'm hoping to eventually work in the fields of marine/coastal conservation, and I expected that this course would provide me valuable scientific knowledge that I could use to better inform my future actions as a policymaker and/or writer.
As a coastal/water resource manager, I think taking classes that are heavily science based is essential to be a good environmental manager. This was definitely one of my favorite classes so far.
My focus is on water and marine resources.
I am interested in coastal ecosystem management.
My wife will probably make us live at the beach and I need to be well-versed in coastal ecosystems in order to find employment.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes - above and beyond.
Yes.
Absolutely.
Yes.
My expectations were exceeded.
Yes.
Yes, absolutely! I learned more about salt marshes than I ever thought possible.
Yes
YES!
Surpassed my expectations.
yes
Yes and then some! really exceeded expectations.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Helpful for studying for the final exam

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the course - although it is a lot of work you really gain a lot from it.
Great course, great hands-on experience.
Don't miss this one if you are interested in coastal and marine issues. Professor Anisfeld is one of the professors that really care about the students' experience.
I wish that I'd studied more for the weekly quizzes.
Do all the readings, do not get behind, it would be very overwhelming to catch up.
Enjoy!
Great class. Heavy workload is worthwhile.

If you prep for the weekly quizzes the final will be a whole lot easier. If youÂ´re a science person who really likes getting into the details this class is for you. IF you prefer more of a 10,000 ft view this class might not be to your tastes.
Do all the readings. You'll thank yourself.And be prepared to dabble in chemistry.
